THE ARGUMENT.</br>In this the Author bewailes the death of one whom he shadoweth under the name of Philarete, compounded of the Greeke words [Greek passage] and [Greek passage], a lover of vertue, a name well befitting him to whose memory these lines are consecrated, being sometime his truly loved (and now as much lamented) friend Mr. THOMAS MANWOOD, son to the worthy Sir PETER MANWOOD Knight.

Under an aged Oke was WILLY laid,</br>WILLY, the lad who whilome made the rockes</br>To ring with joy, whilst on his pipe he plaid,</br>And from their maisters wood the neighb'ring flockes</br>But now o're-come with dolors deepe</br>That nye his heart-strings rent,</br>Ne car'd he for his silly sheepe,</br>Ne car'd for merriment.</br>But chang'd his wonted walkes</br>For uncouth paths unknowne,</br>Where none but trees might heare his plaints,</br>And eccho rue his mone.

Autumne it was, when droop'd the sweetest floures,</br>And Rivers (swolne with pride) orelook'd the bankes,</br>Poore grew the day of Summer's golden houres,</br>And void of sapp stood Ida's Cedar-rankes,</br>The pleasant meadows sadly lay</br>In chill and cooling sweats</br>By rising fountaines, or as they</br>Fear'd Winters wastfull threats.</br>Against the broad-spred Oke,</br>Each winde in fury beares;</br>Yet fell their leaves not halfe so fast</br>As did the Shepherdes teares.

As was his seate, so was his gentle heart,</br>Meeke and dejected, but his thoughts as hye</br>As those aye-wandring lights, who both impart</br>Their beames on us, and heaven still beautifie.</br>Sad was his looke, (O, heavy Fate!</br>That Swaine should be so sad</br>Whose merry notes the forlorne mate</br>With greatest pleasure clad.)</br>Broke was his tuneful pipe</br>That charm'd the christall Floods,</br>And thus his griefe tooke airie wings</br>And flew about the woods.

Day, thou art too officious in thy place,</br>And night too sparing of a wished stay,</br>Yee wandring lamps:  O be ye fix'd a space!</br>Some other hemisphere grace with your ray.</br>Great Phoebus!  Daphne is not heere,</br>Nor Hyacinthus faire;</br>Phoebe!  Endimion and thy deare</br>Hath long since cleft the aire.</br>But yee have surely seene</br>(Whom we in sorrow misse)</br>A Swaine whom Phoebe thought her love,</br>And Titan deemed his.

But he is gone; then inwards turne your light,</br>Behold him there; here never shall you more;</br>O're-hang this sad plaine with eternal night!</br>Or change the gaudy green she whilome wore</br>To fenny blacke.  HYPERION great</br>To ashy palenesse turne her!</br>Greene well befits a lovers heate</br>But blacke beseemes a mourner.</br>Yet neither this thou canst,</br>Nor see his second birth,</br>His brightnesse blindes thine eye more now,</br>Then thine did his on earth.

Let not a shepherd on our haplesse plaines</br>Tune notes of glee, as used were of yore!</br>For PHILARET is dead.  Let mirthfull straines</br>With PHILARETE cease for evermore!</br>And if a fellow swaine do live</br>A niggard of his teares,</br>The Shepherdesses all will give</br>To store him part of theirs.</br>Or I would lend him some,</br>But that the store I have</br>Will all be spent before I pay</br>The debt I owe his grave.

O what is left can make me leave to mone?</br>Or what remains but doth increase it more!</br>Looke on his sheepe:  alas!  their masters gone.</br>Looke on the place where we two heretofore</br>With locked arms have vowd our love,</br>(Our love which time shall see</br>In shepheards songs for ever move,</br>And grace their harmony)</br>It solitary seemes.</br>Behold our flowrie beds;</br>Their beauties fade, and Violets</br>For sorrow hang their heads.

Tis not a Cypresse bough, a count'nance sad,</br>A mourning garment, wailing Elegie,</br>A standing herse in sable vesture clad,</br>A Toombe built to his names eternitie,</br>Although the shepheards all should strive</br>By yearly obsequies,</br>And vow to keepe thy fame alive</br>In spight of destinies</br>That can suppress my griefe:</br>All these and more may be,</br>Yet all in vaine to recompence</br>My greatest losse of thee.

Cypresse may fade, the countenance be changed,</br>A garment rot, an Elegie forgotten,</br>A herse 'mongst irreligious rites bee ranged,</br>A toombe pluckt down, or else through age be rotten:</br>All things th' unpartiall hand of Fate</br>Can raze out with a thought,</br>These have a sev'ral fixed date</br>Which ended, turne to nought.</br>Yet shall my truest cause</br>Of sorrow firmly stay,</br>When these effects the wings of Time</br>Shall fanne and sweepe away.

Looke as a sweete rose fairely budding forth</br>Bewrayes her beauties to th' enamour'd morne,</br>Untill some keene blast from the envious North,</br>Killes the sweet budd that was but newly borne,</br>Or else her rarest smels delighting</br>Make her her selfe betray,</br>Some white and curious hand inviting</br>To plucke her thence away:</br>So stands my mournfull case,</br>For had he beene less good,</br>He yet (uncropt) had kept the stocke</br>Whereon he fairely stood.

Yet though so long hee liv'd not as hee might,</br>Hee had the time appointed to him given.</br>Who liveth but the space of one poore night,</br>His birth, his youth, his age is in that Even.</br>Who ever doth the period see</br>Of dayes by Heaven forth plotted,</br>Dyes full of age, as well as hee</br>That had more yeares alotted.</br>In sad Tones then my verse</br>Shall with incessant teares</br>Bemoane my hapless losse of him,</br>And not his want of yeares.

In deepest passions of my grief-swolne breast</br>(Sweete soul!)  this onely comfort seizeth me,</br>That so few yeares did make thee so much blest,</br>And gave such wings to reach ETERNITY.</br>Is this to dye?  No:  as a shippe,</br>Well built with easie winde,</br>A lazy hulke doth farre outstrippe,</br>And soonest harbour finde:</br>So PHILARETE fled,</br>Quicke was his passage given,</br>When others must have longer time</br>To make them fit for heaven.

Then not for thee these briny teares are spent,</br>But as the Nightingale against the breere</br>Tis for my selfe I mone, and doe lament</br>Not that thou left'st the world, but left'st mee heere.</br>Heere, where without thee all delights</br>Fail of their pleasing powre,</br>All glorious dayes seeme ugly nights;</br>Me thinks no Aprill showre</br>Embroider should the earth,</br>But briny teares distill,</br>Since FLORAS beauties shall no more</br>Be honour'd by thy quill.

And ye his sheepe (in token of his lacke),</br>Whilome the fairest flocke on all the plaine,</br>Yeane never Lambe, but bee it cloath'd in blacke.</br>Ye shady Sicamours!  when any Swaine,</br>To carve his name upon your rinde</br>Doth come, where his doth stand,</br>Shedde droppes, if he be so unkinde</br>To raze it with his hand.</br>And thou, my loved Muse</br>No more should'st numbers move,</br>But that his name should ever live,</br>And after death my love.

This said, he sigh'd, and with o're-drowned eyes</br>Gaz'd on the heavens for what he mist on earth,</br>Then from the earth, full sadly gan arise</br>As farre from future hope as present mirth,</br>Unto his Cote with heavy pace</br>As ever sorrow trode</br>He went, with minde no more to trace</br>Where mirthful Swaines abode;</br>And as he spent the day,</br>The night he past alone,</br>Was never shepherd lov'd more deere,</br>Nor made a truer mone.</br>
